hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Molly broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
9\blueE{3}&\\
\underline{{} \times 5\blueE{1}}&\\
\blueE{3}&\quad \blueE{1} \times \blueE{3}
\end{align}$

There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also,
$\blueE1\times\blueE3=\blueE{3}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
\tealE{9}3&\\
\underline{{} \times 5\tealE{1}}&\\
{3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\
\tealE{90}&\quad \tealE{1} \times \tealE{90}
\end{align}$

There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\tealE1\times\tealE{90}=\tealE{90}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$

$\begin{align}
9\maroonE{3}&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE5{1}}&\\
{3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\
{90}&\quad {1} \times{90} \\
{\maroonE{150}}&\quad {\maroonE{50}} \times\maroonE{3}
\end{align}$

There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also, $\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{3}=\maroonE{150}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $3$.

###Step $4$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{9}{3}&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{5}{1}}&\\
{3}&\quad {1} \times {3}\\
{90}&\quad {1} \times{90} \\
{{150}}&\quad {50} \times{3} \\
\underline{~~~\goldE{4{,}500}}&\quad {\goldE{50}} \times\goldE{90}
\end{align}$

There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\goldE{50}\times\goldE{90}=\goldE{4{,}500}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $4$.

###Step $5$

$\begin{align}
93&\\
\underline{{} \times51}&\\
\purpleE3&\quad 1 \times 3\\
\purpleE{90}&\quad 1 \times90 \\
\purpleE{150}&\quad 50 \times3 \\
+\underline{~~~\purpleE{4{,}500}}&\quad {50} \times{90} \\
\purpleE{4{,}743}
\end{align}$

Molly said that $\purpleE{3 + 90+ 150 + 4{,}500}$ equals $4{,}650$, so Molly made a mistake in step $5$.
Molly made a mistake in step $5$.

question.content:
Molly tried to evaluate $93\times51$ using partial products, but she made a mistake.  Her work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&93 \\
&&\underline{{}\times51} \\
&\blueE{\text{Step 1}}&\blueE{3}& \blueE{1\times3}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 2}}&\tealE{90}& \tealE{1\times 90}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 3}}&\maroonE{150}& \maroonE{50\times 3}\\
&\goldE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\goldE{ 4{,}500}}& \goldE{50\times 90}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{4{,}650}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Molly's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.clue:
There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also,
$\blueE1\times\blueE3=\blueE{3}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $1$.
There is $1$ one in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\tealE1\times\tealE{90}=\tealE{90}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $2$.
There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $3$ ones in $93$.  Also, $\maroonE{50}\times\maroonE{3}=\maroonE{150}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $3$.
There are $5$ tens in $51$ and there are $9$ tens in $93$. Also, $\goldE{50}\times\goldE{90}=\goldE{4{,}500}$, so Molly did not make a mistake in step $4$.
Molly should have added all $4$ of her partial products instead of just the last $2$. So Molly made a mistake in step $5$.
